body.title: What are XML structure diagrams?
body.p: XML markup is an effective means to create structured content . An XML document that conforms to an XML Schema is valid and programs that work with its defined structure know what to do with the document. To create a valid XML document, you must understand its defining schema.
But rather than dive into the technical details of schema specifications, we present here diagrams to describe an XML document's valid structure.

section.title: Structure diagrams
section.p: A box with a label, as shown in the first diagram in the figure How to read a structure diagram, represents an XML element. The description inside the box, if any, indicates what the element may contain. A group of elements that work together is represented by a three-dimensional block, as shown in the second diagram in the figure. Find a group's detailed description in a separate diagram.
A number range indicates the number of occurrences an element or a group may appear (its multiplicity ). If no number range is shown, the required number of occurrences is one.

section.title: Example structure diagram
section.p: In the figure "Diagram showing structure of a topic head element," the identify, history, and index group of elements should appear once in the order shown inside a head element. The figures "Identity group," "History group," and "Index group" then provide the detailed structure for each group.
